\documentclass[border=5pt]{standalone}
\usepackage{pgfplots}
    \pgfplotsset{
        compat=1.3,
    }
\begin{document}
\begin{tikzpicture}
    \begin{axis}[
        % set some parameters
        width=11.5cm,
        height=8cm,
        % define what kind of plots to want
        /pgfplots/colormap/gray,
        % /pgfplots/ytick=\empty, % gets rid of all yticks (including the old standard si:2)
        ytick=\empty,
        % ---------------------------------------------------------------------
        % to be sure no numbers are shown in the plots, hide the `axis'
        % frame
        hide axis,
        % ---------------------------------------------------------------------
        xlabel={$\theta$ [rad]},
        ylabel={Ganancia [$\theta$]},
        % ---------------------------------------------------------------------
        ymin=-0.25,
        % there is no need to use a parametric plot for this
        % so it can be reduced to a normal plot
        samples=200,
        % ---------------------------------------------------------------------
        % change `domain' to the start and end angle of the required
        % sector and provide the corresponding angle at which the
        % sector ends
        domain=0:180,
        % now you can draw the sectors as single plot
        % (using normal plots, you would have got the error
        %  `/pgfplots/pplot/.style {...' because the ticks were
        %  in the way)
        sector plot/.style={
            black,
            thick,
            mark=*,
            mark options={
                black,
            },
            smooth,
            thick,
            mark size=0.05pt,
            % ---------------------------------------------------------------------
            % to draw the lines at the intersection of the sectors, we
            % use the `intersections' library and specify the `name' of the
            % plot (to later be able to distinguish it from the normal plot)
            name=#1,
            % ---------------------------------------------------------------------
            % when drawing the plot, we want to be sure that the
            % lines start at the intersection of the previous sector's
            % end point and the first point of the new sector. This is
            % provided by the `forget plot' command. A special case is
            % the case when the previous sector does not end at the
            % intersection, in which case we draw the line straight to
            % the given end point
            postaction={
                draw=black,
                dashed,
                name=#1,
                forget plot,
            },
            % ---------------------------------------------------------------------
        },
        % ---------------------------------------------------------------------
        % this is the plot I want to have
        % (it is drawn with a parametric plot, which is the cause of
        %  the `domain' parameter)
        red,
        smooth,
        thick,
        mark=none,
        % ---------------------------------------------------------------------
        domain=0:4,
        % now you can draw the plot
        plot (\x,{atan(\x)});
        % ---------------------------------------------------------------------
        % here we draw a normal (non-parametric) plot of the data
        % (`domain' is not needed here I think)
        black,
        % smooth
        thick,
        mark=none,
        % no `cycle list' is needed for this one
        draw=black,
        fill=green,
        % ---------------------------------------------------------------------
        % the blue line
        blue,
        thick,
        mark=none,
        smooth,
        % draw it over the blue background
        scatter/@pre marker code/.code={
            \pgfmathparse{int(\coordindex)}
            \ifnum \pgfmathresult > 0
                % draw a line from the intersection of the blue line and
                % the `black' line to the point where the `blue' line
                % starts
                \draw [green, thick, shorten >=5mm, shorten <=5mm]
                    (axis cs:-1.2, -0.75)
                        -- (axis cs:\pgfmathresult, -0.75);
            \fi
            \def\markernot{*}
        },
        scatter/@post marker code/.code={
            \def\markernot{\relax}
        },
        % ---------------------------------------------------------------------
        % the colormap is drawn over the three sectors
        colormap={gray}{
            color=(black)
            color=(green)
            color=(blue)
        },
        % just for safety, draw a grid
        grid=both,
        grid style={
            gray,
            dotted,
            % when not using a `cycle list', you can't use the `cycle list
            % option with the `draw' style
            draw=gray,
            line width=0.2pt,
            every non major tick/.append style={
                black,
                % I have to use `\pgfkeysvalueof{/pgfplots/major tick length} + 1
                % to get the grid to show at the right location
                line width=1.5\pgfkeysvalueof{/pgfplots/major tick length},
            },
        },
    ]
        \addplot [
            smooth,
            color=red,
            solid,
            line width=0.4mm,
            mark=*,
            mark options={
                red,
            },
            forget plot,
        ] {atan(x)};

        \addplot [
            red,
            smooth,
            solid,
            line width=0.4mm,
            mark=*,
            mark options={
                red,
            },
            % draw this line over the black line (draw=black makes it invisible)
            black,
            % draw a sector plot at the domain of the required plot
            % and name it accordingly
            % (as the name is used as input to the `\pgfkeysvalueof' function,
            %  it can't be used as such)
            sector plot=red,
            domain=0:180,
            % ---------------------------------------------------------------------
            % we don't want to draw a line at the intersection of the
            % previous plot and the first coordinate, so use
            % the `forget plot' command here and provide an appropriate
            % legend entry
            legend style={
                draw=none,
                % legend image code is used, so we can't use a

    \begin{tikzpicture}[baseline]

    row sep=1cm]{
            &&&&&\\[-5mm]

           \ifnum \x=5 1   \else   3\fi   \else   3   \fi \fi\fi\fi  \\
    2   &     \ifnum \x=1 2   \else   3   \fi \else   3   \fi\fi
    &     \else     \ifnum \x>2   \relax     \if

\tikzset{shift value/.store in=\shiftvalue, shift value=2pt}

\matrix[row sep=2pt, column sep=1pt] {
    % Convolutional Layers
    \node[encoder] (E1) { Encoder }; &
    \node[encoder] (G1) { Convolutional kernel R1 }; &

    \node[encoder] (G3) { Convolutional kernel R3 }; &
    \node[encoder] (G4) { Convolutional kernel R4 }; &
    \node[encoder] (G5) { Convolutional kernel R5 }; &
    & \\
    % Input Images
    \node[filter, shift value=-\shiftvalue] (I1) { Input }; &
    \node[filter, shift value=\shiftvalue] (I2) { Input }; &
    \node[filter] (I3) { Mask }; &
    \node[filter] (I4) { Obstacle }; &
    \node[filter] (I5) { Traffic sign }; &
    \node[filter] (I6) { Building }; &
    \node[filter, shift value=-\shiftvalue] (I7) { Thunderstorm }; &
    \\
};

\documentclass{article}
\usepackage{tikz}
\usetikzlibrary{positioning}
\newcounter{nodenumber}
\begin{document}
\begin{tikzpicture}[x=2cm,y=1cm,
    every node/.style={draw,rectangle,minimum width=2em,outer sep=0pt},
    level 1/.style={sibling distance=3cm},
    level 2/.style={sibling distance=2cm},
    level 3/.style={sibling distance=2cm}]
% Start with the parent node, and slowly build out the tree
% with each node representing a new level of the diagram
% each child node represents a new concept / category
% each edge / link represents a possible relationship between
% concepts (if a node has no children, it is undefined)

\node (tree) {see Proposition \ref{prop1}}

    % Now place the nodes one level at a time, writing the text in the
    % node labels
    %
    % parent nodes
    %   child nodes
    %   child nodes
    %   child nodes
    %   child nodes
    %   child nodes
    %   child nodes
    %   child nodes
    %   child nodes
    \foreach \text/\name in {61.70/1,
                            39.50/2,
                            87.60/3,
                            54.67/4,
                            16.17/5,
                            43.53/6,
                            59.70/7,
                            65.67/8,
                            59.50/9,
                            44.68/10,
                            55.14/11,
                            34.33/12,
                            34.92/13,
                            27.30/14,
                            11.18/15,
                            40/16}
        {
            % The text in the node labels
            \node (\name) at (level \number\value{nodenumber}/2) {\text};
            \node[font=\small,below left=0.25cm and 0.3cm of \name] (\name-loc) {\name};
            \stepcounter{nodenumber}
        }

    % Now draw the links / edges
    %   a
    %   b
    %   c
    %   d
    %   e
    %   f
    %   g
    %   h
    \foreach \start/\end in
        {61.70/39.50,
        61.70/87.60,
        39.50/16.17,
        39.50/43.53,
        87.60/54.67,
        54.67/16.17,
        54.67/43.53,
        87.60/59.70,
        54.67/65.67,
        59.70/64.68,
        64.68/59.70,
        59.70/65.67,
        65.67/59.70,
        59.70/59.25,
        44.68/34.33,
        44.68/35.27,
        44.68/46.10,
        30/27.30,
        11.18/40/16,
        11.18/21.22,
        21.22/9.16,
        9.16/4.64,
        21.22/28.93,
        14.33/11.18,
        28.93/15.14,
        46.10/34.92,
        46.10/33.37,
        46.10/32.54,
        32.54/27.30,
        32.54/31.15,
        31.15/26.17,
        16/40/35.27,
        16/21.22/28.93,
        35.27/14.33,
        35.27/15.14,
        35.27/33.37,
        40/28.60,
        21.22/4.64,
        15/11.18,
        09/03/03,
        03/28.60,
        27.30/34.92,
        27.30/32.54,
        27.30/31.15,
        31.15/15.14,
        28.93/34.33,
        34.33/35.27,
        34.33/33.37,
        34.92/27.30}
        {
            % The arrows / lines
            \draw[-] (\start) to (\end);
            \setcounter{nodenumber}{0}
        }

    % Now place the node labels above the tree diagram as a separate
    % set

    % Node labels below the diagram
    \node[below=1.5cm of tree] (label-a) {a};
    \node[below=1.5cm of label-a] (label-b) {b};
    \node[below=1.5cm of label-b] (label-c) {c};
    \node[below=1.5cm of label-c] (label-d) {d};
    \node[below=1.5cm of label-d] (label-e) {e};
    \node[below=1.5cm of label-e] (label-f) {f};
    \node[below=1.5cm of label-f] (label-g) {g};
    \node[below=1.5cm of label-g] (label-h) {h};
    \node[below=1.5cm of label-h] (label-i) {i};

    % Separated node labels left of the tree
    \node[left=1.5cm of a] (label-aa) {a};
    \node[left=1.5cm of b] (label-ab) {b};

\documentclass[tikz,border=3.14mm]{standalone}

\tikzset{ % from https://tex.stackexchange.com/a/423952/121799
common/.style={rounded corners,top color=white,bottom color=black!20,draw=black},
mtraj/.style={matrix of math nodes,common,top color=white,bottom color=black!20,nodes={draw},column sep=0.3cm,row sep=0.2cm,nodes in empty cells,anchor=west},
schematics/.style={common,draw=black,thick,fill=white,rounded corners, prefix after command= {\pgfextra{\tikzset{every label/.style={font=\scriptsize}}}} }
}
\newcommand\schemestrip[2][]{\begin{tikzpicture}[baseline=(X.base),>=stealth,node distance=0.6cm,semithick]%
        \matrix  (#2) [schematics] {%
            \node (X) {#1}; &  \node (Y) {#1}; & \node (Z) {#1};\\};
        \node[fit=(#2),inner sep=0pt] (B) {}; %Fit the sturcture
        \draw (B.south west) -- (B.north west) -- (B.north east) -- (B.south east) -- cycle;%Outline
        \node[above of=X,yshift=-0.5cm] (LABl) {#1}; %Label left
        \node[above of=Y,yshift=-0.5cm] (LABl) {#1}; %Label right
        \draw[->] ([xshift=0.2cm]LABl.east) to[out=-45,in=-135] ([xshift=0.2cm]X.west); %Draws the arrow
    \end{tikzpicture}}
